Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                       Peachtree City, GA


INTRODUCTION
The city of Peachtree City, GA seeks to study conditions along the SR 54 corridor from MacDuff
Parkway in the west to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road in the east for the purpose of
identifying a series of operational improvements designed to reduce congestion along the
heavily traveled road. The study area is approximately 1.4 miles in length. See Figure 1 for a
project location map.

The corridor is classified by the Georgia Department of Transportation (GDOT) as a principal
arterial road. The road also serves as a state route and is a primary east-west connection
between Coweta County and Fayette County. SR 54 also provides access to SR 74 which is a
north-south arterial that has an interchange with I-85 10 miles north of Peachtree City. The SR
54 arterial is a 45 mph, four lane divided highway with partially restricted access to large
residential and commercial areas north and south of the corridor. Three major retail generators
located within the study area include Wal-Mart, The Home Depot, and The Avenue shopping
center. Two large residential areas are accessed by Planterra Way and MacDuff Parkway. An
industrial area is accessed by Huddleston Road and is a large generator of peak hour commuter
trips.

The corridor is currently experiencing heavy AM, PM, and Saturday peak hour congestion.
Queuing occurs along the entire length of the corridor at peak times and backs up significantly
into retail parking lots and onto residential side streets. In addition to the existing congestion
occurring on State Route 54, two new developments will be completed within the next 1-2 years
that will increase traffic volumes. The first development is The Overlook at Line Creek Drive on
the southern side of the road. This development is expected to be a series of retail stores. The
second development will be the West Village community located along MacDuff Parkway to the
north. An extension of MacDuff Parkway is planned as part of this development and will
connect to Senoia Road and SR 74 north of the corridor. This extension is expected to draw a
portion of traffic traveling between SR 54 and SR 74.

This traffic study examines the corridor for possible causes to the existing congestion and will
make a series of recommendations based on alternative testing through the use of computer
modeling software. The study will also focus on recommendations at the two previously
mentioned planned developments to accommodate additional traffic generated by these trip
sources. Additional considerations include maintaining and enhancing access to existing
commercial areas and providing for future growth within and outside of Peachtree City limits.




                                              -4-
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                               State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                              Peachtree City, GA

TECHNICAL METHODOLOGY
The technical analysis conducted in this study is based on intersection operations. In addition,
the future traffic conditions have been forecast based on anticipated planned developments and
roadway connections in the area. These volumes were derived from existing traffic studies and
through the use of the Atlanta Regional Commission’s (ARC) travel demand model. The
technical methods are described in detail below.

INTERSECTION ANALYSIS METHODOLOGY
In this study, the methodology used for evaluating traffic operations at intersections is based on
the criteria that is set forth in the Transportation Research Board’s Highway Capacity Manual
2000 (HCM). The HCM is the standard recognized manual for conducting traffic analysis
throughout the country.          Trafficware Synchro 8 software, which emulates the HCM
methodology, was used for the analysis. The following is a description of the methodology
employed for the analysis of unsignalized and signalized intersections.

Level of Service (LOS) is an indication used to describe the operations of an intersection. For
unsignalized intersections, the LOS is determined by control delay for the turning movements at
the intersection and minor street crossing movements. Several factors affect the control delay
including the availability and distribution of gaps in the conflicting traffic stream, critical gaps,
and follow-up time for a vehicle in the queue.

LOS is assigned a letter designation from A through F. LOS A indicates excellent operations
with little delay to motorists, while LOS F exists at unsignalized intersections when there are
insufficient gaps of acceptable size to allow vehicles on the side street to cross or turn safely.
This condition will result in extremely long control delays and long queues. The LOS criteria for
unsignalized intersections, as defined in the HCM, are given in Table 1.

Table 1: Level of Service Criteria for Unsignalized Intersections
      Level of Service (LOS)               Control Delay (s/veh.)
                A                                  0 - 10
                B                                >10 - 15
                C                                >15 - 25
                D                                >25 - 35
                E                                >35 - 50
                F                                   >50
Source: Highway Capacity Manual 2000

Level of service (LOS) for a signalized intersection is a qualitative measure and is defined in
terms of control delay per vehicle (in seconds per vehicle). Control delay refers to the portion of
total delay that can be attributed to the traffic signal operation for signalized intersections.
Control delay depends upon a number of variables including traffic volumes, lane configuration,
the quality of progression of traffic from adjacent intersections, the cycle length, and the ratio of



                                                 -6-
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                              State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                             Peachtree City, GA


green time to the cycle length. The level of service criteria for signalized intersections, based on
control delay, is shown in Table 2. Level of service A indicates operations with very low control
delay while level of service F describes operations with extremely high control delay. Level of
service F is considered to be unacceptable by most drivers. Level of service D is typically
considered to be the limit of acceptable delay in urbanized areas.

Table 2: Level of Service Criteria for Signalized Intersections
 Level of Service    Control Delay per Vehicle (s/veh.)
        A                          < 10
        B                        >10 - 20
        C                        >20 - 35
        D                        >35 - 55
        E                        >55 - 80
         F                           >80
Source: Highway Capacity Manual 2000

The intersection LOS is an important factor in examining transportation needs and testing
potential solutions. However, there are other considerations such as property access, safety
and constructability that can also be used as an evaluation tool when comparing alternatives.

BACKGROUND TRAFFIC GROWTH
This study examines solutions for short-, mid-, and long-term timeframes. To do so, traffic
growth must be accurately predicted. Two sources were used to estimate traffic growth along
the corridor and in the surrounding area. The first source is historic data from GDOT traffic
counters. These counters provide reasonable AADT counts and can illustrate regional growth
trends. Table 3 shows the AADT and growth rates at four locations within the study area.

                Table 3: GDOT Traffic Count Volumes and Historic Growth Trends
                                                                    AADT                Growth Rate
        TC #                      Location
                                                           2012     2010     2008     3-year   5-year
                          SR 54 east of Willowbend
 TC #0183                  Road/Flat Creek Road            23,800   21,820   22,130   2.5%       NA
 TC #0182              SR 54 east of Huddleston Road       44,550   40,110   28,000   3.6%      9.7%
 TC #0118              SR 74 north of Aberdeen Pkwy.       30,370   29,610   28,630   0.8%      1.2%
 TC #0116              SR 74 north of Crosstown Road       15,860   14,290   15,630   3.5%      0.3%


The GDOT counts suggest a strong growth rate over the last 3-year period and 5-year period for
SR 54. Notably, the 74 corridor has shown less yearly growth than the 54 corridor. Future
trends can be expected to reflect moderate growth on SR 54, but not likely as strong as what
has occurred in the past 5 years. This is due to the fact that development has been accelerated
but is likely to level off as build-out conditions are reached in areas immediately adjacent to SR
54.




                                                     -7-
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                           State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                          Peachtree City, GA


The second source of traffic growth predictive data is the Atlanta Regional Commission’s (ARC)
travel demand model. This model uses socio-economic data such as population, household
income, and employment figures to estimate the trips generated and the routes taken by
individuals. Several model scenarios were run to analyze the future traffic on SR 54 and to
estimate the impacts of the planned roadway connections of MacDuff Parkway, TDK Boulevard,
and Minix Road Connector. Forecasted daily traffic volumes and the methodology used to
calibrate the ARC travel demand model can be found in Appendix A of this document.

The daily volumes produced by the model can be seen in Table 4. The Base Year scenario
was conducted using 2013 socio-economic data, while the 2040 Build scenario consisted of the
future alternative in which the West Village is built-out and MacDuff Parkway Extension is
complete.

The background traffic growth rate for each segment of highway in the study area was derived
from these ARC models. The SR 54 corridor retained a constant growth rate of 1.07% per year
based on growth between Huddleston Road and Willowbend Road. The SR 74 corridor
exhibited two distinct growth patterns north and south of SR 54. South of SR 54, the growth
rate is estimated to be relatively strong at 2.00% per year. North of SR 54, the rate drops to an
average of 0.75% per year. These values are also in line with the assumption that future long-
term growth will not be as strong as the GDOT historic trends have shown in the recent past.

           Table 4: ARC Travel Demand Model Volumes and Predicted Growth Trends
                                                              Model Run             Growth
                           Location
                                                                                   Rate/year
                                                        Base Year    2040
      SR 54 west of MacDuff Pkwy.                        37,045      60,744         1.85%
      SR 54 between MacDuff Pkwy. and Huddleston Road    45,831      52,867         0.53%
      SR 54 between Huddleston Road and SR 74            45,174      57,890         0.92%
      SR 54 between SR 74 and Willowbend Road            28,212      39,149         1.22%

      SR 74 between TDK Blvd. and Paschall Road          15,754      27,147         2.04%
      SR 74 between Paschall Road and SR 54              12,940      21,812         1.95%
      SR 74 between SR 54 and Aberdeen Pkwy.             26,713      32,624         0.74%
      SR 74 north of Aberdeen Pkwy.                      21,176      25,925         0.75%


The short- to mid-term timeframe is a 10 year period of growth. The year 2024 was used as the
target date for these analyses. The long-term timeframe analyzes the corridor at a target date
in the year 2040 to remain consistent with ARC’s current comprehensive plan and travel
demand models. These yearly growth rates were applied to turning movement counts to
develop the background traffic volumes. The following section describes additional trip
generation and distribution that was conducted to reflect the planned neighborhoods along
MacDuff Parkway.




                                                  -8-
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                       State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                      Peachtree City, GA


TRIP GENERATION AND DISTRIBUTION
To predict the influence of the MacDuff Parkway Extension and additional residential
developments, a series of steps were used:
    1. Determine the volume of daily cut-through traffic on MacDuff Parkway Extension from
       the travel demand model. This value was determined to be approximately 3,400 vpd in
       2040. This value was reduced to 2,800 vpd in 2024 based on a 1.07% per year growth
       rate.
    2. Use the existing k-factor to determine the peak hour volumes on MacDuff Parkway
       generated by cut-through traffic. Directional distribution patterns can be assumed from
       the eastbound left turn volumes and southbound right turn volumes at the intersection of
       SR 54 and SR 74.
    3. Determine the daily traffic distribution of residential traffic on MacDuff Parkway between
       the northern and southern termini of the road by subtracting the cut-through traffic at
       each endpoint.
    4. Determine the daily trips generated by the planned developments along MacDuff
       Parkway using the Institute of Transportation Engineers Trip Generation Manual.
    5. Use the existing k-factor to determine the peak hour trips at the intersection of MacDuff
       Parkway with SR 54. Use existing turning patterns to estimate the direction of travel at
       the intersection.
    6. Add any additional turning movements generated by new developments at the corner of
       SR 54 and MacDuff Parkway (i.e., new restaurant).
A breakdown summary of these calculations can be found in Appendix B of this document,
along with final turning movement diagrams for years 2024 and 2040.




                                              -9-
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                         State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                        Peachtree City, GA


EXISTING CONDITIONS
This section outlines the traffic data collected along the SR 54 corridor for use in this study. It
also describes the intersection analysis results for the corridor and identifies areas of queue and
delay. Lastly, this section details the forecasting methodology used to develop future volumes
and turning movement patterns.

TRAFFIC COUNTS
Traffic counts were conducted in February and April 2014 at the locations described below. The
count locations are listed below and are found in Figure 2. Raw data from these counts can be
found in Appendix C of this document.

24-hour Bidirectional Volume Count with Vehicle Classification and Speed (weekday and Sat.)
   1. SR 54 west of Planterra Way                      2. SR 74 north of SR 54
24-hour Bidirectional Traffic Volume Count (weekday and Sat.)
   3. MacDuff Parkway north of SR 54                   7. Market Boulevard west of SR 74
   4. City Circle south of SR 54                       8. Chart Court east of SR 74
   5. Dixie Circle west of SR 74                       9. SR 54 west of Peachtree Parkway
   6. Clover Reach (northern intersection)             10. Planterra Way south of SR 54
       west of SR 74                                   11. Kelly Green west of Dividend Drive
Weekday AM and PM Peak Period (7-9 AM and 4-6 PM) and Sat. Peak Period (1:30-3:30 PM)
Turning Movement Count (TMC)
   12. SR 54 at Huddleston Road                        14. SR 54 at SR 74
   13. SR 54 at Market Place Boulevard
Weekday PM Peak Period ONLY (4-6 PM) and Sat. Peak Period (1:30-3:30 PM) TMC
   15. SR 54 at MacDuff Parkway                        20. SR 54 at Willowbend Road/Flat
   16. SR 54 at Line Creek Drive                           Creek Road
   17. SR 54 at Planterra Way                          21. SR 74 at Clover Reach
   18. SR 54 at West Park Walk                         22. SR 74 at Westpark Drive
   19. SR 54 at Willowbend
       Road/Northlake Drive

The traffic counts indicate that the Average Daily Traffic (ADT) on SR 54 in the study area is
approximately 35,730 vehicles per day (vpd). The ADT on SR 74 north of the study area is
approximately 29,160 vpd. The daily volumes on SR 54 suggest that the 4-lane road is
currently experiencing overcapacity conditions.

Existing traffic volumes from weekday counts can be seen in Figure 3. The existing weekend
traffic volumes can be seen in Figure 4. Please note that at MacDuff Parkway, Line Creek
Drive, and Planterra Way, the AM turning movement counts from the Traffic Impact Study for
The Overlook Development, conducted by GCA Engineering in January 2014, were used.
These turning movement figures can be found in the Appendix D of this document.

EXISTING INTERSECTION LOS
The intersection analyses was performed for the AM, PM and Saturday peak hour using
Trafficware Synchro software, version 8, explained earlier. The capacity of each intersection
was determined and the LOS was interpreted for each approach, as shown below in Table 5.
Synchro reports for all analyses are included in Appendix E of this report. Please note that
existing signal timing plans were provided by GDOT and used for this analysis. Additionally, the
ideal saturation flow rate was reduced from 1900 vehicles/hour/lane (vphpl) to 1600 vphpl to
simulate the higher than normal saturation headway existing today that is caused by the steep
grade ascending the bridge over the CSX railroad tracks between Market Place Boulevard and
Huddleston Road. Observations of the site led to this reduction in the model.

   Table 5: Peak Hour Intersection Level-of-Service (LOS) and Delay, 2014 Existing Conditions
Peak Hour Intersection Level-of-Service (LOS)                        2014 Existing Conditions
                                                       AM Peak             PM Peak            Sat. Peak
                   Intersection                            Delay                Delay               Delay
                                                    LOS    (sec)         LOS    (sec)       LOS     (sec)
SR 54 at MacDuff Parkway                             F       109.7         B       18.1         B    19.3
SR 54 at Line Creek Drive-Unsignalized
        NB Approach                                  F       56.3          C       19.8         E    40.6
        SB Approach                                  C       19.5          C       15.7         C    15.6
        EB Left Turn Lane                            B       10.5          B       13.8         B    12.4
        WB Left Turn Lane                            D       27.0          B       13.7         C    15.1
SR 54 at Planterra Way/Wal-Mart Driveway             F       120.0         D       36.4         E    76.0
SR 54 at Huddleston Road                             D       36.6          D       51.4         E    77.9
SR 54 at Market Place Boulevard/The Avenue           A        4.7          C       20.6         D    35.4
SR 54 at SR 74                                       E       76.8          E       79.4         F    80.5
SR 54 at Commerce Drive-Unsignalized
        SB Approach                                      -     -           B       12.5         B    10.4
        EB Left Turn Lane                                -     -           A        9.6         A    10.0
SR 54 at Willowbend Road/Northlake Drive                 -     -           C       34.8         C    32.5
SR 54 at Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                 -     -           C       22.6         A    9.5


The existing condition levels of service illustrate AM bottlenecks at MacDuff Parkway, Planterra
Way and SR 74. The PM levels of service for each intersection are acceptable, however the
westbound approaches in the model experience extensive queuing, which likely causes worse
levels of service than actually shown by the Synchro model. Additionally, side streets along the
corridor experience delays corresponding to LOS “F” and long queues during the PM peak.
Saturday congestion occurs in both eastbound and westbound directions, leading to poor LOS.
Side streets experience failing delays during the weekend peak time as well. PM and Saturday
bottleneck intersections along SR 54 are located at SR 74, Huddleston Road, and Planterra
Way.




                                                - 14 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                      State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                     Peachtree City, GA


OBSERVED QUEUE AND DELAY

AM Peak Hour
The corridor experiences long queues and extended delays during peak times. During the AM
peak, queues form along SR 54 from the intersection with SR 74 back to the west into Coweta
County. Figure 5 illustrates the AM peak period congestion and bottleneck locations. Primary
sources of this congestion are commuters traveling from Coweta County to several destinations
within the study area and beyond. A large office park in the northern quadrant of the SR 54 and
SR 74 intersection serves as a primary traffic generator. Additionally, an industrial area
accessed via Huddleston Road creates demand to the south. Primary bottleneck locations
during the AM period are at SR 74 and at Huddleston Road. The steep grade of the CSX
railroad crossing causes the bottleneck at Huddleston Road because vehicle headway over the
bridge is greater than average headway values. The bottleneck at SR 74 is caused by the
protected left turns and high demand in the north-south direction that must also be served by
the signal.

                                Figure 5: AM Peak Hour Queues




PM Peak Hour
Figure 6 illustrates the PM peak period queues and bottleneck locations that form in the
afternoon. The corridor during this time of day is characterized by very slow moving congestion
in the westbound direction and along some major side streets. The 4-lane road is unable to
accommodate the peak hour demand, which is one primary source of the congestion. Frequent


                                           - 15 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                         State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                        Peachtree City, GA


signal spacing is also a contributing factor to the slow progression of traffic, as signals at
Huddleston Road, Planterra Way and The Avenue/Market Place Boulevard act as bottlenecks.
These side streets also experience long queues during the afternoon peak. The queues are
largely a result of a heavy volume of vehicles leaving the industrial area to the south of the study
area. These vehicles use the side streets of Huddleston Road and Planterra Way to access SR
54. This demand on side streets is not served adequately by the green time that the signals at
Planterra Way and Huddleston Road provide, and therefore, queues form and vehicles must
wait through multiple cycles before being able to move through the bottleneck signals.
                                 Figure 6: PM Peak Hour Queues




Traffic Traveling Through Corridor in AM and PM Peak Hours
The AM and PM Peak Hours experience significant volumes of traffic traveling all the way
through the SR 54 corridor from Coweta County to east of Willowbend Road. The volume and
percent of traffic that travels all the way through the corridor in the peak travel direction during
the AM and PM peak hours is indicated below.
    • AM Peak Hour (Eastbound Direction)
            o 610 veh travel all the way through the corridor
            o 33% of the 1800 total entering vehicles from west
            o 64% of the 960 exiting vehicles to east
    • PM Peak Hour (Westbound Direction)
            o 615 veh travel all the way through the corridor
            o 80% of the 765 total entering vehicles from east
            o 33% of the 1870 exiting vehicles to west



                                           - 16 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                        State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                       Peachtree City, GA



Saturday Afternoon
Saturday congestion forms in much the same way as it does during the weekday afternoon,
except commuter traffic is not the primary generator of demand. The retail that is located along
the corridor serves as the primary traffic generator on weekends. Traffic backs up extensively
into shopping center parking lots during the weekend peak, and drivers must often wait through
multiple cycles before being able to exit retail sites. Side street volumes are not being provided
with enough green time to serve the traffic during the long cycles and delays become excessive
due to this timing. Figure 7 illustrates the location of weekend traffic generators, queuing and
bottlenecks.

                              Figure 7: Saturday Peak Hour Queues




                                           - 17 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                          State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                         Peachtree City, GA


NEEDS ASSESSMENT
This section outlines current deficiencies along the corridor. These needs have been identified
through observations, computer modeling, and city input. Alternatives for testing were
developed based on these identified needs and preferred recommendations are described later
in this report.

CORRIDOR CONGESTION
The corridor experiences a morning commute capacity problem as traffic travels east from the
Coweta/Fayette County line towards SR 74. The coordinated signal systems provide a
substantial amount of green time to move as much traffic through the strained system as
                                                        possible, but this leads to some
                                                        delay on side streets providing
                                                        residential access like Planterra Way
                                                        and MacDuff Parkway. The signals
                                                        at these two locations become
                                                        bottlenecks for through traffic as
                                                        evidenced by the existing LOS in
                                                        Table 5. SR 54 at SR 74 is also a
                                                        bottleneck because of the need to
                                                        provide significant green time for the
                                                        north-south direction. AM queues
                                                        can extend along SR 54 for 1.50
            AM Queues in the Eastbound Direction        miles back to Fischer Road at times,
while SR 74 queues are short and the approaches are generally less congested than SR 54.
Signal timing modifications at the SR 54 and SR 74 intersection may relieve some of the
congestion in the short term, but the problem is derived from an overall capacity deficiency
along the corridor.

The PM commute time is more problematic than the morning commute due to the higher
volumes of traffic traveling through the corridor and traffic traveling to and from the side streets.
This is due to the presence of significant volumes accessing the retail developments along SR
54, which is not present in the AM peak hour. The queuing that occurs during the PM extends
along the westbound side of the highway and backs up through the intersection with SR 74.
Again, the signal spacing causes some of this congestion by requiring traffic to make additional
stops. This is particularly apparent at the intersections with Huddleston Road and Market Place
Boulevard where stopped cars are required to begin moving up the steep grade of the bridge
spanning the CSX railroad tracks. The increase in saturation headway caused by this grade
significantly impacts the volume of cars served by the signals’ green time.




                                           - 18 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                            State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                           Peachtree City, GA


With the additional traffic generated
by the retail along the corridor, side
street operations become more
important in the afternoon than in the
morning. A substantial amount of
green time is provided for SR 54
westbound traffic which causes long
delays leaving retail such as The
Avenue, Wal-Mart, and The Home
Depot.

The weekend congestion occurs
much in the same way as the
afternoon weekday congestion, but

queues form in both east- and              Cars Ascending the Steep Grade at Market Place Blvd. (PM Peak)
westbound directions.

THE AVENUE/MARKET PLACE BOULEVARD TRAFFIC SIGNAL BOTTLENECK
This signal is located just west of the major intersection of SR 54 and SR 74. During the
afternoon and weekend peaks, it acts as a significant bottleneck for through traffic on the
corridor. On weekdays, this signal stops traffic just before the steep railroad crossing. As a
result, when cars receive the green signal, they must begin their ascent of the bridge from a full
stop which impacts the throughput of the signal. One challenge of this particular intersection is
that it is the only full access point into the large retail center known as The Avenue. Ideally, the
existing signal should be removed from the mainline and access should be restricted to reduce
the number of vehicles that must come to a complete stop before crossing the bridge, but
consideration must be given to the retail that uses this signal.

PLANTERRA WAY & HUDDLESTON ROAD PM AND SATURDAY QUEUES
A significant employment generator is located south of the corridor and is accessed by
Huddleston Road. Employees leaving this industrial area can reach SR 54 by going north on
Huddleston, by going north on SR 74, or by making their way through residential streets to
Planterra Way. Congestion at the SR 54 at SR 74 intersection can lead to long delays for
northbound left turns, so commuters have begun using Planterra Way as a secondary exit from
the industrial area. The intersections of SR 54 with Huddleston Road and Planterra Way are
not designed to accommodate the demand for left turns that these drivers are placing on the
northbound approaches. Residents of the neighborhoods accessed by Planterra Way have
indicated that long queues form which makes leaving their homes at this time of day difficult and
that the volume of cut-through traffic is disruptive to the neighborhood.

Geometric constraints at both of these intersections also contribute to the overall poor levels of
service. At Huddleston Road, the northbound approach is skewed and rises on a steep grade
to SR 54. Drivers making this approach may not be aware of opposing traffic leaving the Best


                                            - 19 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                       State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                      Peachtree City, GA


Buy retail center because visibility is impaired by the grade and angle of approach. The
capacity of the approach is also reduced because of the additional startup time caused by the
steep grade. At Planterra Way, the southbound approach has dual left turn lanes leaving the
Wal-Mart and The Home Depot. The intersection is not wide enough to accommodate
simultaneously operating these dual left turn lanes with the single northbound left-through lane,
therefore, the signal is currently split-phased (a less effective signal operation where one side
street is served then the other, instead of both moving simultaneously). Both the northbound
and southbound approaches (side streets) have significant PM volumes and the split-phasing
does not allow for them to be served adequately. The split phasing also increases the delay for
the westbound directional traffic, which impacts the corridor congestion.

LINE CREEK DEVELOPMENT
The parcels south of the SR 54 corridor at Line Creek Drive are currently in the design phase of
development. The latest traffic impact study conducted for the Overlook development was
completed in January 2014 and investigated the impacts of approximately 94,954 sq. ft. of retail
space, 4,860 sq. ft. of fast food, and a gas station with 20 fueling pumps. The development will
increase the volumes along the corridor and will also increase the number of turning movements
at the unsignalized intersection. The impact study determined that a signal is warranted for
adequate access to the new development; however, the signal spacing along the corridor is
currently contributing to the congestion problems. An additional connection from the shopping
center to Planterra Way is proposed and the impacts to traffic caused by this secondary access
point at the residential street were investigated in this study.

A possible connection to the MacDuff Crossing retail center just west of the development site
could serve as the primary access point for The Overlook without the need to add an additional
signal. This connection would make use of the existing signal at MacDuff Parkway and would
still provide unsignalized access to the site via Line Creek Drive. This connection’s impacts on
traffic along the corridor was investigated in this study.
The site plan and turning movement figures from the GCA Engineering study can be found in
Appendix D of this document.

WEST VILLAGE/MACDUFF PARKWAY EXTENSION
A planned development known as the West Village will be located north of the SR 54 corridor
along MacDuff Parkway. This development will consist of an additional 1359 single family units
and 204 senior living units. As part of the development, the MacDuff Parkway will be extended
north and connect to Senoia Road and SR 74. This new construction will have significant
impacts to the SR 54 corridor and were investigated in this study. For instance, the ARC travel
demand model that was modified to reflect these conditions in Peachtree City indicates that the
new extension could be expected to divert approximately 3,300 vpd from SR 54, which is
beneficial to controlling demand on the corridor. The new residential units will also generate
additional trips and are expected to impact intersection operations at SR 54 at MacDuff
Parkway.




                                           - 20 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                              State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                             Peachtree City, GA




QUADRANT CONNECTIVITY AND ACCESS
Currently,      quadrant       connectivity
around the SR 54 and SR 74
intersection is limited at several
locations.       When connectivity is
limited, it forces drivers to return to the
SR 54 corridor rather than using
access roads to travel between retail
locations. The existing railroad tracks
limit this inter-quadrant access;
however a connection between the
northern and western quadrants
would provide a means of access
between each area without using SR
54 or SR 74.              This could be
accomplished by installing a signal at
Westpark Drive, which would make
crossing SR 74 possible. Currently it
is very difficult for drivers on Westpark
Drive and the Market Place Connector
to cross or turn left onto             the             Quadrant Connectivity and Signal Spacing
unsignalized 6-lane highway.

Signal spacing is also a concern along the SR 54 corridor in this area. As seen in the image
above, the signal spacing along SR 74 is ideal (illustrated with green circles), with adequate
distance between median breaks. Along SR 54 the spaces between signals is shorter
(illustrated with red circles), which makes coordination more difficult. However, as previously
mentioned, the signal at The Avenue is the only full access point for this retail center and
removing it could affect the businesses located in this shopping center and to the north along
Market Place Boulevard. The signal here also acts as an inter-quadrant connection point, which
makes its removal difficult.

DRIVER SAFETY
One intersection on SR 54 has been identified as a high crash location by the city; this
intersection is the unsignalized “T” east of SR 74. Commerce Drive is the southbound stop-
controlled approach, and SR 54 is free-flowing to the east and west. The southbound left turn
movement is of particular concern because it requires drivers to cross 2 lanes of heavy traffic
and enter the eastbound vehicular stream without the use of a median refuge. Drivers also
have to be aware of uncommon U-turn movements from the east.




                                              - 21 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                         State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                        Peachtree City, GA


2024 TRAFFIC ALTERNATIVES ANALYSIS
This section of the report documents several solutions to the problems identified in the needs
assessment section. These solutions are characterized as being projects that are feasible in
the short-term or the mid-term range. A no-build scenario using forecasted traffic volumes
described in the previous section was modeled to establish a baseline for measuring
effectiveness. The Synchro reports from this no-build scenario, and all other alternatives that
were modeled, can be found in Appendix F of this report.

ACCESS MANAGEMENT TO ADDRESS CLOSELY SPACED INTERSECTIONS
One contributing factor to the PM and Saturday congestion west of the intersection with SR 74
is the closely spaced signals along the corridor. The first signal west of SR 74 is the Market
Place Boulevard/The Avenue crossing, located 900’ to the west. The next signal is
approximately 750’ to the west at Huddleston Road. The grade of the road between SR 74 and
Huddleston Road is as steep as 10% on the bridge. The frequent stops combined with the
steep grades in the westbound direction are acting to reduce overall capacity of the road by
causing cars to stop and then ascend the grade from a full stop. To reduce the number of stops
at the bridge, two scenarios were tested at the Market Place Boulevard/The Avenue signal:
    • Remove the signal and restrict access by dividing the highway with a median
    • Modify the signal by replacing the existing 4-legged signal with a continuous green “T”

                                                               A continuous green “T” is a type
                                                               of signal that allows one direction
                                                               of travel to be continuously
                                                               flowing. This signal type can only
                                                               be used at “T” intersections,
                                                               therefore, the side-street leg of
                                                               the existing intersection at Market
                                                               Place Boulevard would need to be
                                                               modified to a right-in/right-out only
             Continuous Green "T" in Bluffton, SC                 access point.
                                                                  Both scenarios would require
                                                  relocating the full-access point to the northwest
                                                  quadrant. The ideal location for this new full-
                                                  access point is on SR 74 north of its
                                                  intersection with SR 54 at Westpark Drive.
                                                  Currently the intersection is unsignalized, and
                                                  would require a signal if it were to serve as the
                                                  primary entry point to the northwest quadrant.
                                                  A preliminary examination of daily turning
                                                  volumes at the location of this proposed signal
                                                  has been conducted.          The existing traffic
                                                  patterns have been modified to account for
    Continuous Green "T" in Johns Creek, GA
                                                  additional left turns at the site that are


                                           - 22 -
    Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                                              State Route 54 Corridor
    Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                                             Peachtree City, GA


    expected to be caused by removing the left turn capability at SR 54 at Market Place Boulevard
    and at SR 54 at Commerce Drive. Table 6 below shows the results of the signal warrant
    analyses. Detailed information regarding the signal warrant analysis can be found in Appendix
    G of this document.

                                                               meet an additional need to improve quadrant
                                                               connections between the northwest quadrant and

                                                  restricting left turns into and out of Commerce
                                                  Drive. The left turns would be redirected to the
      Proposed Signal Location and New Connection new signal and served by a left turn phase.
    Upon completion of the Westpark Drive/Aberdeen Parkway connection, drivers who wished to
    travel east on SR 54 could use the new connection to access Flat Creek Road and bypass
    significant segments of SR 54 completely. These improvements are also expected to enhance
    access for the office parks located along Westpark Drive and Commerce Drive.

    An intersection analysis was conducted at Market Place Boulevard/The Avenue to determine
    what impacts each alternative had on PM and Saturday levels of service and queues in 2024.
    The results are shown below in Table 7.

    Table 7: 2024 PM and Sat. Peak Hour LOS, Delay and Queues; Access Management at The Avenue
                                          PM Peak                                                Saturday Peak
     Alternative              Delay        WB     NB             SB                  Delay      EB       WB           NB         SB
                       LOS    (sec)       Queue Queue           Queue        LOS     (sec)     Queue Queue           Queue      Queue
No Build                C        24.7     1,118’     242’       102’          E       74.2     1,112’      1,038’     176’       41’

                                                       - 23 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                          State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                         Peachtree City, GA


The results of the alternatives analysis show that the median restriction would generate the
most significant improvement to queues during the study period. However, this option relies on
restricting access to Market Place Boulevard and The Avenue retail center to right-in/right-out
drives, which may have unwanted impacts on businesses in these areas. Notably, the existing
signal is the only signalized entrance into The Avenue, and removing it would require an
additional signal at another location along SR 74. However, the existing median break at Clover
Reach does not provide adequate spacing to the adjacent intersection at Paschall Road.

Use of the continuous green “T” signal would restrict SR 54 access at Market Place Boulevard
to a right-in/right-out driveway. In this case, the signalized access would be moved to a new
signal proposed for the intersection of SR 74 at Westpark Drive. This location has an existing
median break and is located over 1,600 feet from SR 54.

Signalized access to the Avenue would remain on SR 54, served by the continuous green “T”.
The continuous green “T” signal can be very flexible in coordinated systems because it enables
the signalized approach to be coordinated in one direction without impacting progression in the
other direction. The continuous green “T” signal provides significant improvements in LOS and
delay during the Saturday Peak Hour and, most importantly, prevents stops and queuing it the
critical area along SR 54 westbound west of SR 74, which currently spills back to SR 74,
interfering with signal operations (highlighted in the table above).

MANAGING CRITICAL INTERSECTIONS
Huddleston Road and Planterra Way were identified in the needs assessment as being critical
intersections for improvements because of their high side street traffic demand. Short term
improvements should be a focus for the city to improve corridor progression and reduce side
street queues. Operations at these two intersections are interrelated because of the industrial
area traffic that is generated south of the corridor on Huddleston Road. As previously
mentioned, cut-through traffic from this industrial area on the residential street of Planterra Way
is causing heavy queues in the PM peak. The intersection’s signal is split phased as well
because the southbound dual left turn lanes leaving Wal-Mart conflict with the northbound left
turn lane from Planterra Way. Two intersection modifications were analyzed to identify their
impacts:
    • Install dual NB left turn lanes at Huddleston Road, realign the northbound approach of
        Huddleston Road to intersect with SR 54 perpendicularly, and reduce approach grade
    • Construct a left turn lane at Planterra Way, convert the existing shared though and left-
        turn lane at Planterra Way into a through-only lane, reduce length of the eastern median
        nose on the westbound approach to allow for a larger turning radius for southbound left
        turns, and remove split phasing

Improving the intersection of Huddleston Road and SR 54 should encourage greater use of this
route to/from the industrial area to the south, which will relieve some of the cut-through traffic at
Planterra Way. Improving the intersection at Planterra Way will provide additional relief to the
congested side street approaches by improving their capacity.



                                           - 24 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                                           State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                                          Peachtree City, GA


Table 8 shows the PM levels of service, delay and queue length at each intersection. The PM
peak time was the only period that was analyzed due to the fact that the queuing is present
during the weekday rush hour.

   Table 8: 2024 PM Peak Hour LOS, Delay and Queues; Bottleneck Intersection Improvements
                                                                                 PM Peak
                            Scenario                                  Delay       WB     NB          SB
                                                             LOS      (sec)      Queue Queue        Queue

               F* - long queue spillback results in high delay and LOS F conditions


As this table shows, the short term improvements recommended at these intersections will have
operational benefits; however, significant delays and queuing exist. An increase in overall
corridor capacity for the westbound direction is necessary to provide significant improvements
and reduction in critical queues (recommended as a mid-term improvement).

ACCOMMODATING NEW DEVELOPMENTS
Two new developments along the corridor have been identified and their impacts were analyzed
in this section. Those developments are The Overlook at Line Creek Drive and the West Village
DRI on MacDuff Parkway.

The Overlook at Line Creek Drive
Signalization alternatives for The Overlook development at Line Creek were examined in detail
as part of the larger corridor study. A Traffic Analysis Report prepared by GCA, dated January
17, 2014, for development of a Chik-Fil-A restaurant, RaceTrac Gasoline Station, and 95,000
square feet of retail space along SR 54 in Peachtree City recommends signalization of the
intersection of SR 54 at Line Creek Drive. The GCA traffic study includes a signal warrant
analysis that indicates MUTCD Warrant 1B-Interruption of Continuous Traffic is satisfied.
However, signalization of Line Creek Drive does not meet GDOT spacing standards (1000 ft
min. between signals) and the high levels of congestion and frequent signals along SR 54 have
caused concern regarding installation of an additional traffic signal. GDOT requested that
signalization and alternative means of access be examined in the context of the SR 54 corridor
to determine the effects of signalization or other access.




                                                    - 25 -
   Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                                          State Route 54 Corridor
   Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                                         Peachtree City, GA


   The alternatives that were analyzed included:
      1. A full signal at Line Creek Drive
      2. A continuous green “T” signal at Line Creek Drive
      3. Unsignalized access at Line Creek Drive with a connection to the Planterra Way traffic
          signal
      4. Unsignalized access at Line Creek with a connection to MacDuff Crossing/MacDuff
          Pkwy. signal (requires reconstruction of the northbound approach of MacDuff Crossing
          to include an exclusive left turn lane and traffic signal modifications to allow for protected
          left turns)

   Two performance factors were critical to comparison of alternatives for these critical
   movements: Intersection delay (and resulting LOS), as well as queue length. Where queues
   extend between intersection, the operation of the downstream intersection will be severely
   limited by interaction with queued traffic. This results in delay that is frequently much higher than
   that reported by traffic modeling.

   The PM peak hour and Saturday Peak hour were the focus of this analysis, due to higher levels
   of congestion along SR 54 during those time periods and the fact that retail uses, such as the
   proposed Overlook development are more active during those times of day. Results of the PM
   Peak hour analysis can be found in Table 9.

              Table 9: 2024 PM Peak Hour LOS, Delay and Queues; The Overlook Development
                                       Planterra Way Intersection             Line Creek Drive Int.     MacDuff Pkwy. Int.
           Scenario                        Delay     WB         NB                   Delay      WB          Delay      WB
                                     LOS   (sec)   Queue Queue               LOS     (sec)    Queue   LOS   (sec)   Queue
No Build (No Line Creek Dev.)         F*         -       1,556’      385’   D (NB)   26.2      -       C     34.1    282’
1) Full Signal at Line Creek          F*         -       1,647’      434’     C      20.4     199’     D     38.2    555’
2) Continuous Green “T”               F*         -       1,651’      434’     B      19.5      0’      D     39.4    275’

   As this table shows, the Planterra Way intersection experiences long queues and high approach
   delay during the PM peak hour for the westbound approach (which spills back beyond
   Huddleston Road) and the northbound approach (which extends towards the Tennis Center
   Driveway). Due to this high level of delay, the alternative to provide access to Planterra Way
   only with unsignalized access at Line Creek Drive results in the worst level of operations for
   Planterra Way, with high delay and NB queues (see highlighted area in Table 9). Major
   intersection improvements would be needed to mitigate the effects of the additional traffic
   volumes at this intersection if a connection to Planterra Way were the only access to the
   Overlook development.



                                                            - 26 -
        Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                                                State Route 54 Corridor
        Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                                               Peachtree City, GA


        Potential impacts to signal coordination with implementation of a signal at Line Creek Drive
        were investigated to determine whether or not traffic progression was effected by the signal
        type. Due to the traffic signal spacing, the full signalized intersection would create difficulties for
        two-way signal progression along the corridor. The continuous green “T” offers more flexibility
        for signal coordination because only one direction must be stopped for side street movements
        (eastbound direction). The stop for the eastbound direction can be coordinated with the side
        street movements at the Planterra Way and McDuff Parkway intersections without impacts to
        the westbound traffic flow. The Table above shows that queues in the westbound direction
        spilling back from MacDuff Parkway to Line Creek or from Line Creek to Planterra are not
        expected to be a problem with a full signal during the PM peak hour, due to the current
        bottleneck condition at Planterra Way, which limits traffic flow to the west.

        Table 10 compares the operation of SR 54 with Saturday afternoon traffic for conditions with
        both the continuous green “T” and a full signal at Line Creek and conditions with no signal at
        Line Creek and a connection to MacDuff Parkway.

        Table 10: 2024 Saturday Afternoon Peak Hour LOS, Delay and Queues; The Overlook Development

        As this table shows, the full signal results in eastbound queuing that spills to adjacent signalized
        intersections (highlighted cells), resulting in additional stops and delay beyond those indicated in
        the table. Adjustment of signal timing (green offset time) to reduce the eastbound queues
        shown in the table above would results in queuing in the westbound direction which is more
        congested overall during PM peak and Saturday peak periods. The eastbound queues still form
        when the continuous green “T” is modeled at Line Creek Drive, but do not spill back to the
        intersection of SR 54 and MacDuff Parkway.




                                                                - 27 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                             State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                            Peachtree City, GA


The unsignalized intersections at Line Creek Drive with a connection to MacDuff Parkway
(Alternative 4) results in similar operations to the signalized options but does not require an
additional signal and avoids overloading the Planterra Way signal (corridor bottleneck). A
northbound left turn lane would be needed at the MacDuff Parkway signal in addition to
improvements to the southbound approach needed with additional development along MacDuff
Parkway.

Alternative 2 is the preferred signalization type for this intersection because it provides
significant additional flexibility in coordinating with adjacent signals. During peak times which
experience heavy traffic flow in both directions, such as Saturday and the PM peak hour, the
continuous green “T” can be coordinated so that the eastbound delays are limited without
concern about the effects to signal coordination in the westbound direction, which does not stop
for the signal.

West Village DRI on MacDuff Parkway
The additional trips generated by the West Village residential developments along MacDuff
Parkway are expected to impact operations at the intersection with SR 54.               These
improvements are expected to be minor geometric modifications and are expected to be
feasible within a relatively short term. These modifications include:
   • Widen the southbound approach to accommodate dual southbound left turn lanes as
        well as an adjacent, parallel auxiliary left turn lane for access to the Discount Tire
        shopping center.

The 2024 AM, PM, and Saturday LOS and delay for this improvement are shown in Table 11.

ADDITIONAL WESTBOUND CAPACITY
A primary concern with the corridor is the constrained capacity during the PM and Saturday
peak times. The 4-lane road does not provide enough capacity to meet the peak demands,
resulting in congested conditions. Widening the road to a 6-lane road would be ideal, but
financial and scheduling constraints may limit the improvements that can be made to the
corridor in the mid-term. The most severe congestion occurs in the westbound direction on
weekdays in the afternoon rush hour, and Saturday afternoon. Therefore, increasing westbound
capacity in the most congested area is the most important capacity improvement. Several
scenarios were considered for a limited widening of the WB direction and include:
        • Ending the third through lane at the existing right turn lane into Wal-Mart/The Home
            Depot.
        • Ending the third through lane at the existing right turn lane onto MacDuff Parkway.
        • Taking the third through lane through the intersection with MacDuff Parkway and
            tapering down to two lanes further west.

The PM LOS and queue results from the Synchro model at 4 critical intersections for each
scenario are found in Table 12.

    Table 12: 2024 PM LOS and Queue at Critical Intersections; Additional Westbound Capacity
                             Market Place          Huddleston Road/Best
                                                                             Planterra Way/Wal-Mart        MacDuff Parkway
                         Boulevard/The Avenue              Buy
       Scenario
                                         WB                       WB                           WB                         WB
                         LOS Delay Queue           LOS Delay Queue           LOS     Delay    Queue     LOS     Delay    Queue
No-Build                   C*       24.7    1,118’    F*      -       1,871’    F*        -      1,647’    D       38.2     555’
Third Lane to Planterra
Way                         B       18.0     203’     D     36.4      1,056’    F*        -      1,637’    D       38.2     558’
Third Lane to MacDuff
Parkway                     B       18.0     203’     C     34.1      1,056’    D        42.1     456’     D       41.1     986’
Third Lane through
MacDuff Parkway             B       18.0     203’     C     34.1      1,056’    D        42.1     456’     D       37.4     202’
F* - long queue spillback results in high delay and LOS F conditions. C* - Queue spillback reaching from Huddleston Road through
Market Place to SR 74 may result in high delay and gridlock conditions resulting in LOS F when queues block intersection
movements.

In addition to delay and level of service, Table 12 shows highlighted the locations where queues
spill back to adjacent intersections, resulting in poor corridor and intersection LOS. The results
from this analysis suggest that the alternative that provides the most benefit to traffic operations
along the corridor is to carry the third through lane to or past MacDuff Parkway. It should be
noted that ending the third lane at Planterra Way/Wal-Mart does not improve queue length at
this intersection due to the lane change maneuver that drivers would have to make when the
lane is dropped. The additional westbound capacity also provides significant relief to overall
intersection delay during weekend peak times, as well as significant reduction to queues in the
westbound direction.




                                                       - 29 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                         State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                        Peachtree City, GA


The raised median is wide enough to accommodate an additional lane and retain the existing
footprint of the roadbed at most locations along SR 54. Figure 8 illustrates the existing typical
cross section of the highway, with grassed median area and the offset left turn lanes commonly
found in GDOT type B median crossover designs.

                                Figure 8: Typical Section of SR 54




Reconstruction of the median area would be required for the entire length of the project. The
lanes would also need to be narrowed from 12’ to 11’ in the westbound direction. The resulting
cross section would resemble the illustration shown in Figure 9.

                   Figure 9: Proposed 5-lane Mid-term Cross Section for SR 54




One benefit of this solution is that it allows for the addition of an entire third through lane over
the grade separated railroad crossing without relying on widening of the bridge structure.




                                           - 30 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                      State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                     Peachtree City, GA


Figure 10 illustrates the existing and proposed bridge structure cross sections. Construction
east of the bridge should include modifying the southbound right turn lane at the intersection
with SR 74 from a channelized lane with a yield condition to a free-flowing channelized lane.
The southbound right turn lane storage area should also be lengthened 310’ back to the right
in/right out driveway at Market Place Boulevard. At a later date, the intersection of SR 54 and
SR 74 can be widened to take the third westbound lane through the intersection, thereby
increasing the overall capacity of the intersection itself.

        Figure 10: Existing and Proposed 5-lane Mid-Term Cross Sections at CSX Bridge




                                           - 31 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                                             State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                                            Peachtree City, GA


ADDITIONAL EASTBOUND CAPACITY
The corridor experiences heavy congestion in the morning eastbound commute as a result of
demand exceeding the highway’s capacity. The impacts are not as extensive in the morning as
they are at other times of the day due to the fact that traffic on side streets is lower in the
morning than in the afternoon or on weekends. However, as growth in Peachtree City and
neighboring counties continues to develop, the over-capacity condition will have a greater
impact on mobility.

The impacts of the additional capacity on level of service and delay at each signalized
intersection west of SR 74 can be found in Table 13. These results suggest that the demand on
the 54 corridor in the year 2024 will be met by adding a third lane in each direction at all peak
times of the day. The intersection of SR 54 and SR 74 is expected to operate on the threshold
between the “E” and “F” level of service. Further improvements to this intersection will be
examined in the “2040 Traffic Alternatives Analysis” section of this report.

              Table 13: 2024 AM, PM and Sat. Peak Hour LOS and Delay; 6 Lane Corridor
                                          2024 No Build Scenario                     2024 6 Lane Highway Scenario
 Signalized Intersection     AM Peak           PM Peak          Sat. Peak        AM Peak       PM Peak        Sat. Peak
                           LOS     Delay     LOS    Delay      LOS    Delay     LOS   Delay   LOS    Delay   LOS   Delay
 SR 74                       F      82.8       F    104.2       F     106.4      E    59.8     F     101.7    E     72.5
 Market Pl. Blvd. / The
 Avenue                      A      5.5       C      24.7       E      74.2      A     5.4     B      18.5    C     27.4
 Huddleston Road             E      59.2      F*       -        F     132.3      A     7.7     C      31.0    C     24.6
 Planterra Way              F*     159.4      F*       -        F     153.8     C     20.7     D      39.8    E     61.8
 MacDuff Parkway              F     138.8       D      38.2    D       38.5     D     49.5     D      36.0    C     27.9
         F* - long queue spillback results in high delay and LOS F conditions


The primary goal of Peachtree City should be to widen the highway to a 6-lane road from just
west of MacDuff Parkway through the intersection with SR 74. The widening can be conducted
in multiple phases if necessary. As previously stated, the westbound direction should be
widened first, and the eastbound direction can be widened at a later date. Consideration should
ultimately be given to extending the 6 lane section west into Coweta County to Fischer Road to
accommodate growing traffic from Coweta County.

The new lanes can also be contained within the existing footprint for almost the entire length of
the project by narrowing each lane from 12’ to 11’, and by using the existing median space for
through lanes. Figure 11 illustrates the corridor’s existing typical section, the proposed interim
section including the third westbound through lane, and a proposed final section of a 6-lane
highway with 11’ lanes.

and traffic operations, effects on queues, how many vehicles are required to stop, ease of
construction and whether the improvement restricts accessibility to retail and residences. This
comparison matrix was devised to illustrate the decision-making process that was used to
develop the final recommendations in this report.

Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                         State Route 54 Corridor

The geometry of the green “T” intersection requires the minor street left turns to merge with
adjacent vehicles which creates a weaving section of road. The alternatives that consist of a
weaving section have been noted in Table 14. Both locations are upstream of an existing left
turn lane, and therefore, a weaving section would be created between merging vehicles from
the side street and vehicles in the mainline that wish to merge over to use the left turn lane. The
weaving sections at Line Creek Drive and The Avenue are expected to operate between an
LOS of “B” and “C” by 2040 during the PM peak hour. Results of this study are located in
Appendix G. A red block represents poor conditions, a yellow block represents no change or
marginal improvements, and a green block represents good conditions.

From Table 14, the following alternatives were selected as short-term and mid-term
recommendations for the corridor. These projects would address immediate deficiencies in the
network and establish a logical progression of improvements based on the availability of funds
and areas of need. This document contains figures showing these recommendations.

SHORT-TERM RECOMMENDATIONS
Modify Access Points Close to SR 54 at SR 74 Intersection
   • Install a continuous green “T” signal at the existing intersection of SR 54 and Market
       Place Boulevard/The Avenue. Cut off Market Place Boulevard from SR 54 and redirect
       traffic to a proposed new signal at the intersection of SR 74 and Westpark Drive.
   •   Restrict left turns to and from Commerce Drive at its intersection with SR 54, by
       converting this intersection to a right-in and right-out only. These left turns would be
       redirected to the new signal as well.
Modify Bottleneck Intersection of Planterra Way to Improve Efficiency of Side Street Movements
  • Widen the northbound approach of Planterra Way to accommodate an exclusive left turn
       lane. The median nose that sticks out into the intersection from the east can be
       shortened to allow a broader turn radius for left turns exiting the Wal-Mart/The Home
       Depot driveway. The intersection should be widened to the point that both side-street
       left turn movements can operate concurrently, and thereby removing the need to split-
       phase the signal.
Modify MacDuff Parkway Intersection to Accommodate Current Needs and Additional Traffic
due to Planned Development
   • Widen the southbound approach of MacDuff Parkway and construct a northbound left
       turn lane into the Discount Tire retail site. This northbound left turn lane should be
       adjacent and parallel to the existing southbound left turn lane to prevent an end-to-end
       geometric condition that limits the length of both directional turn lanes. Additionally, the
       widening should accommodate a second southbound left turn lane to aid in meeting
       peak demand for this turning movement.
   •   Construct an access road to connect the Overlook development to MacDuff Parkway via
       the MacDuff Crossing shopping center. Coordination will be required between the
       developer, the city, and the owner of the MacDuff Crossing property. Additionally, an



                                           - 35 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                                             State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                                            Peachtree City, GA


         exclusive left turn lane should be constructed at the existing signal on the northbound
         driveway of MacDuff Crossing.
Signalize the Intersection of SR 54 and Line Creek Drive with a Continuous Green “T” to
Accommodate Additional Traffic due to Planned Development
   • Upon completion of The Overlook development at Line Creek Drive, the access point
        should be given a traffic signal in the form of a continuous green “T”. The northern leg of
        the existing intersection should be converted into a right-in/right-out driveway. The side
        street left turns should be guided by a channelization island into an added lane that will
        end approximately 660’ from the proposed signal where the lane will become the
        westbound left turn lane into MacDuff Crossing. The 660’ section should be designed to
        allow cars from The Overlook to weave with cars turning left into MacDuff Crossing.


BENEFITS TO SHORT-TERM RECOMMENDATIONS
These short-term recommendations provide necessary intersection operational improvements
while remaining feasible given the current funding conditions of Peachtree City. Table 15
illustrates the resulting intersection LOS improvements during AM, PM and weekend peak
times. Reduction in queue length and spillback between intersections was also considered to
be an important measure of effectiveness, therefore, cells that are highlighted red indicate a
condition where vehicle queues exceed the signal spacing. A cell is highlighted grey if the
improvements reduce queue length, but spillback to upstream intersection still occurs.
Table 15: 2024 AM, PM and Sat. Peak Hour LOS and Delay and Queue; Short Term Improvements
                                          2024 No Build Scenario                     2024 Short Term Improvements
 Signalized Intersection     AM Peak           PM Peak          Sat. Peak        AM Peak        PM Peak       Sat. Peak
                           LOS     Delay     LOS    Delay      LOS    Delay     LOS   Delay   LOS    Delay   LOS   Delay
 Willow Bend
 Rd./Northlake Dr.          N/A     N/A       D      37.1       C      34.0     N/A    N/A     D      37.5    C     32.4
 SR 74                       F      82.8       F    104.2       F     106.4      F    84.5     F      89.1    F    101.4
