 Huddleston Road             E      59.2      F*       -        F     132.3      E    65.3     F*      -      F     88.2
 Planterra Way              F*     159.4      F*       -        F     153.8      F    92.3     D      38.7    F    111.2
 Line Creek Drive            E      66.1      C      20.4       B      19.5      B    14.3     C      20.5    B     18.8
 MacDuff Parkway              F     138.8       D      38.2    D       38.5      E    78.4     C      32.2    D     40.2
         F* - long queue spillback results in high delay and LOS F conditions


These short-term recommendations benefit intersection operations by targeting bottleneck
locations such as the split-phased signal at Planterra Way and the westbound traffic signal at
the intersection of SR 54 and Market Place Blvd. that results in increases in headway leading up
the railroad bridge crossing. In addition to the reductions in delay and queue length at localized
intersections, the short term improvements also benefit corridor operations too.




                                                           - 36 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                       State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                      Peachtree City, GA


Three corridor performance measures were selected as indicators of operational improvement:
   •   Vehicular Average Speed - Vehicular average speed along the corridor is a measure of
       the ability to travel at free-flow speed, which is used to identify congestion.
   •   Average Arterial Delay - Arterial delay is a way to measure the extent of congestion by
       approximating the total vehicle-hours of delay for a corridor. Delay comes from several
       sources such as the induced delay caused by traffic signals, lengthy startup time caused
       by excessive queuing, and queue spillback into upstream signals which can significantly
       limit the throughput of functioning signals.
   •   Average Travel Time - Average travel time for a corridor was chosen as a third
       performance measure. Travel time is related to many other factors, including arterial
       speeds and delay. Reduction of average travel time on a corridor translates into less
       time spent within the system and is a very noticeable measure of effectiveness for users
       of the roadway.
Table 16 illustrates the average change in each of these measures during the AM, PM and
weekend peak times, as well as the total average effect over all three periods.
  Table 16: 2024 AM, PM and Sat. Peak Hour Performance Measure Improvements; Short Term
                                    % Change in PM from ST Improvements
             Performance Measure
                                     AM         PM       Sat    Average
                                               <5%
         Avg Arterial Speed (mph)   +33%      change    +25%     +20%
                                               <5%
         Avg Arterial Delay (hr)    -18%      change    -21%      -13%
                                               <5%
         Avg Travel Time (hr)       -17%      change    -17%      -12%



On average, the corridor is expected to see an average increase in travel speeds of 20% by
implementing the aforementioned short term recommendations. Delay is expected to decease
as well due to the implementation of green “T” signals and improvements to the timing plan to
improve signal coordination.
The PM peak hour experiences the least improvement to the performance measures because of
the severe capacity deficiency present during this time period. Although changes in
corridorwide average performance during the PM peak period is not a benefit of the short term
recommendations, these improvements do result in significant reductions in delay and queuing
at individual intersections. This will allow more vehicles to traverse this congested corridor
during the PM peak hour, increasing overall throughput and thereby reducing the duration of the
congested period. In other words, the PM period is congested enough that the short term
recommendations will improve individual intersection delay and increase throughput of vehicles.
However, enough vehicle demand exists that the overall delay of the corridor is not likely to
change significantly. As indicated earlier, additional capacity is needed to provide overall
improvement of PM peak hour conditions to acceptable levels of service.




                                           - 37 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                         State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                        Peachtree City, GA




MID-TERM RECOMMENDATIONS
Modify Bottleneck Intersection of Huddleston Rd. to Improve Efficiency of Side Street
Movements
   • Realign the northbound approach of Huddleston Road and widen it to accommodate a
      dual left turn lane. The realignment should be designed to position Huddleston at a
      perpendicular intersection with SR 54, rather than the skew that it currently has. This
      realignment makes drivers more visible to oncoming traffic from the Best Buy driveway.
      In addition to the realignment, the grade should be adjusted to reduce the hill climbing
      needed prior to entering the intersection.
Provide Additional Capacity along SR 54 in the Congested Westbound Direction
   • The southbound right turn lane on SR 74 north of its intersection with SR 54 should be
       lengthened back to the existing right-in/right-out driveway of Market Place Boulevard. A
       free-flowing lane should be constructed in the westbound direction on SR 54 beginning
       at this extended right turn lane. This lane will require reconstruction of existing curb and
       gutter just west of the intersection of SR 54 and SR 74, but should transition into the
       existing footprint before reaching the CSX railroad bridge crossing. At this transition
       point, the existing median will be used to construct a third through lane that will continue
       along the corridor through the intersection with MacDuff Parkway and then taper back
       down to the existing two lanes.
   •   As a mid-to-long range project, the city should consider coordinating with GDOT and the
       counties of Fayette and Coweta to extend the 6-lane section of SR 54 from MacDuff
       Parkway to Fischer Road in Coweta County. This intersection represents the
       convergence point of several major state routes (SR 54 and SR 34) as well as the
       arterial road, Lower Fayetteville Road. Future growth will continue to escalate peak hour
       traffic volumes and therefore, the ultimate goal of an inter-county connection with
       appropriate capacity should be a priority for the city and other invested parties.
Connect Commerce Drive area to Residential Area to the Northeast
   • Construct a new roadway between Westpark Drive and Aberdeen Parkway to promote
      use of the new signal and to provide a direct connection to retail on SR 54 for residences
      to the north on Flat Creek Road and Riley Parkway.

Provide Additional Capacity along SR 54 in the Eastbound Direction and East of SR 74
   • Create a third eastbound through lane on SR 54 by converting the existing median into a
       travel lane. This lane should extend from west of MacDuff Parkway through the
       intersection with SR 74. The resulting highway will be a 6-lane road constructed in two
       phases.
   •   Extend the third through lane in the westbound direction back through the intersection of
       SR 54 and SR 74 to Commerce Drive. This will involve widening the intersection to
       accommodate an extra lane in each direction.




                                           - 38 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                        State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                       Peachtree City, GA


Plan Parallel Connections to SR 54 Corridor
   • Coordinate with County and regional planning efforts, such as the Fayette County
       Comprehensive Transportation Plan (CTP) and Atlanta Regional Transportation Plan
       (RTP) to examine and develop new parallel connections between Fayette County and
       Coweta County. These include connections north – between SR 54 and Castlewood
       Road and south – between SR 54 and Rockaway Road.

BENEFITS TO MID-TERM RECOMMENDATIONS
The mid-term recommendations are designed to provide more capacity to the entire corridor.
These are construction projects that will require significant design and construction, and
therefore have been placed within the mid-term implementation timeframe. Efforts should be
made now to begin planning these projects and coordinating with GDOT, Fayette County and
Coweta County to improve the corridor, with particular attention paid to improving the
westbound capacity.

Currently, the system is a 4-lane divided highway with heavy development and closely spaced
signals through the study area. An estimated maximum daily capacity for LOS “E” operations is
35,100 vpd. This value is for a Class II State Signalized Arterial and is taken from the Florida
Department of Transportation’s (FDOT) 2009 FDOT Quality/Level of Service Handbook which
derives various thresholds of operation for state arterials from the 2010 Highway Capacity
Manual. The estimated current daily volume for SR 54 (from the Atlanta Regional Commission’s
travel demand model) is 45,800, resulting in a volume-to-capacity ratio of 1.3, indicating a daily
operational range equivalent to an LOS “F”.

The ARC’s model also suggests that the corridor could experience daily volumes of
approximately 55,000 vpd or greater by 2040, which indicates a significant capacity deficiency.
If those volumes are reached, the 6-lane corridor recommended in this study could reach
congested conditions by 2040. This is not surprising since this corridor serves as one of the few
connections between Fayette and Coweta counties. Further, the SR 54 corridor connects the
fast growing areas of Fayetteville, Peachtree City, and Newnan, while providing connection to I-
75 and I-85. With strong growth planned in these communities and traffic volumes along SR 54
projected to provide near capacity conditions for a 6-lane road by year 2040, the pursuit of
additional east-west connections both north and south of SR 54 is important. This study
examined the potential benefits of additional connections to the south, as an extension of TDK
Boulevard, and to the north, as a connection between McDuff Parkway and Minix Road. These
scenarios are examined in the Technical Memorandum for Documentation of Travel-Demand
Modeling Work for this study, found in Appendix H. As these modeling runs indicate, either
connection is expected to draw approximately 12,000 vpd with 1/3 of that number as a direct
reduction to traffic along SR 54 between Coweta and Fayette Counties.




                                           - 39 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                                        State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                                       Peachtree City, GA


2040 TRAFFIC ALTERNATIVES ANALYSIS
This section outlines several long-term alternatives that were tested to determine their
advantages and disadvantages. The corridor currently suffers from peak over-capacity
conditions, and is expected to continue to experience failing conditions in the future. The short-
term and mid-term recommendations made in the previous section are expected to relieve the
congestion on the highway in year 2024 however, a third, long-term analysis was needed to
investigate operations of the 6-lane section in the year 2040. Traffic volumes used in this
analysis can be found in the appendix of this document.

INTERSECTION CAPACITY ALONG SR 54
Table 17 shows the LOS and delay for each signalized intersection under no-build conditions
and with the 6 lanes in place. The results of these models suggest that the intersection of SR
74 and SR 54 is likely to be congested and continue to experience excessive delays on
weekends and during the morning commute. The intersection with MacDuff Parkway also
experiences delays that equate to a level of service of “F”. GDOT is currently in the process of
modifying the signal timing along the highway and also has plans to install traffic cameras to
assist in dynamically monitoring and controlling traffic progression. The effects of these
improvements on the corridor by year 2040 are difficult to predict; therefore, for the purposes of
this traffic study these projects were not considered in the 2040 analysis.

              Table 17: 2040 AM, PM and Sat. Peak Hour LOS and Delay; 6 Lane Corridor
                                        2040 No Build Scenario                  2040 6 Lane Highway Scenario
 Signalized Intersection    AM Peak          PM Peak          Sat. Peak     AM Peak       PM Peak        Sat. Peak
                           LOS   Delay     LOS    Delay    LOS     Delay   LOS   Delay   LOS    Delay   LOS   Delay
 Willow Bend
 Rd./Northlake Dr.         N/A   N/A         E     55.8     D       36.6   N/A    N/A     D      51.9    C     34.0
 SR 74                      F    130.3       F    183.8      F     199.4    F    99.2     F      83.3    F    101.8
 Market Pl. Blvd. / The
 Avenue                    A      7.8       D      52.4      F     166.7    A     5.7     B      17.5    D     35.7
 Huddleston Road            F    107.9       F    128.3      F     229.9    A     9.6     D      39.0    E     55.9
 Planterra Way              F    238.0       F    125.3      F     241.9    F    94.7     E      60.2    F     99.8
 MacDuff Parkway            F    205.0      D      45.7      E      63.7    F    87.3     D      36.6    C     33.3


As this table indicates, the SR 54 corridor is expected to experience severe delay and
congestion by year 2040 with its current 4-lane configuration. Also, the corridor will be nearing
its overall capacity in year 2040 with the recommended widening to 6-lanes.

ALTERNATIVE INTERSECTION DESIGNS FOR SR 54 AT SR 74
From the results in Table 17, the intersection of SR 54 and SR 74 could be expected to have
excessive congestion by 2040, even with the widening of SR 54 to a 6-lane highway. Long term
recommendations center on making modifications to the intersection to improve its operations.
The three scenarios that were studied are described below.




                                                      - 40 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                             State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                            Peachtree City, GA


By 2040, the volume of turning movements being made on several approaches to the
intersection of SR 54 and SR 74 exceeds the capacity of what will be in place. The northwest-
bound left turn lane, which is presently a dual left turn lane, is forecasted to approach 750 vph
during the weekend peak. While the intersection does have dual left turn lanes, adding a third
turning lane could improve throughput on the approach. Additionally, the right turns from the
northeast-bound approach are expected to exceed 400 vph during peak times. With the
existing lane geometry, these movements would be required to use a single right turn lane and
the total volume would well exceed the capacity of this single lane. Therefore, a more
appropriate lane configuration would be to convert this single turn lane into dual right turn lanes.
The use of right-turn overlaps with protected left turn phases on SR 74 could increase capacity.

A second alternative for the intersection consists of constructing a grade-separated “left turn
overpass.” This design minimizes the horizontal footprint of the intersection by adding a vertical
component. The left turn overpass removes left turns from the mainline in each direction and
directs vehicles up a ramp to an
elevated overpass.      The left
turns are made at this grade-
separated                location
independently of the through
movements underneath. This
type of design can significantly
improve        the      mainline
intersection because it does
away with the need to protect
left turns and the signal can
operate with just two phases.
The left turns can be controlled
by a two-phase signal as well
since there are no through             Left Turn Overpass Concept – Source: University of Maryland,
                                         Applied Technology and Traffic Analysis Program (ATTAP)
movements on the overpass.

The third alternative that was
explored was a continuous flow
intersection (CFI).           These
intersections operate with a
system of coordinated signals
that divert left turn traffic across
the opposing lanes prior to
reaching the intersection. By
doing so, the left turns are no
longer have to cross the
conflicting     traffic    at    the   Continuous Flow Intersection, US 34 (Eisenhower Blvd.) & Madison Ave.
intersection and can move                          - Loveland, Colorado – Source: Google Earth




                                             - 41 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                                                  State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                                                 Peachtree City, GA


simultaneously with the through movements. These types of intersections do require larger
footprints because the left turn lanes are usually separated by raised medians and typically
require dual lanes to provide adequate storage for high turning movement volumes in a
constrained space. These intersections are not common, but use of the design is growing
around the United States. Designs that displace traffic to unfamiliar sides of the road (with
physical separation of traffic flows) are becoming more common. The diverging diamond
interchange, such as the one in place at the I-285 at Ashford-Dunwoody interchange, is one
such example of a design that requires drivers to travel on the opposite side of the road. The
Synchro model results for each of the three scenarios are found below in Table 18.

        Table 18: 2040 AM, PM and Sat. Peak Hour LOS and Delay; SR 54 at SR 74 Concepts
                                                                                   2040 Peak Hour
                         Concept                             AM Peak                PM Peak                 Sat. Peak
                                                       LOS       Delay       LOS         Delay        LOS        Delay
   6 Lanes on SR 54 – no additional modifications       F        130.3         F         183.8         F         199.4
   Modified Turn Lanes                                  E         70.4        E           71.5         F          90.2
   Left Turn Overpass*                                D/C      37.2 / 20.0   D/C       39.2 / 21.1    C/E      32.4 / 59.7
   Continuous Flow Intersection**                       C          27.3         D         48.3         D          43.4
        *LOS and Delay reported for main intersection and signal at overpass
        **Denotes the signal with the worst LOS and Delay within the signal system

LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS
The results of the 2040 analysis indicate that the expected growth for the region will continue to
put pressure on the capacity of the corridor and the major intersection of State Routes 54 and
74. Intersections of SR 54 with minor side streets appear to operate at a level of service “D” or
better, with exceptions at Planterra Way, Huddleston Road, and MacDuff Parkway. However,
signal retiming and dynamic traffic monitoring efforts currently underway by GDOT should help
reduce overall delay at these minor streets. The most notable failure is at the intersection of SR
54 and SR 74 which is expected to be over-capacity in 2040. Therefore, it is recommended that
some type of major intersection improvement be considered at this location. The addition of a
third left turn lane on the northwest-bound approach and a second right turn lane on the
northeast-bound approach would improve capacity for very heavy turning movements (south to
west/west to south) but only marginally improves intersection LOS from an “F” to an “E” during
weekday peak times. It is recommended, therefore, that a less common concept be
implemented at this location.

Improve Capacity at Critical Intersection
   • A Continuous Flow Intersection (CFI) or a left turn overpass at the crossing of state
      routes 54 and 74 is recommended. Either alternative is expected to provide adequate
      levels of service on all approaches and would not limit existing access points to retail in
      the quadrants of the intersection. The footprint of either option is not expected to require
      removal of any structures, but could require use of retaining walls on the northern side of
      the southwest-bound leg where steep grades down to Westpark Walk’s parking lot
      currently exist.



                                                      - 42 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                       State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                      Peachtree City, GA


In addition, increasing the connectivity between Peachtree City/Fayette County and Coweta
County is needed to reduce volume demand on the few connecting corridors, including SR 54.
Construct Parallel Connections to SR 54 Corridor
   • Construct additional east-west connections between Peachtree City and Coweta County
       parallel to SR 54, including a connection between Rockaway Road and SR 54 and a
       connection between SR 54 and Castlewood Road.



RECOMMENDATIONS AND IMPLEMENTATION PLAN
The congestion that is being experienced along SR 54 is due to an excess of demand that
cannot be accommodated by the current 4-lane highway. Other circumstances such as closely
spaced signals, connection limitations caused by the existing railroad tracks, and frequent stops
and starts along the steep grade of the bridge between Market Place Boulevard and Huddleston
Road also contribute to the congestion problem. Projects such as the completion of the
MacDuff Parkway Extension to Senoia Road are expected to relieve some of the demand, but
these reductions in volume will not solve the problem the City of Peachtree City faces. To solve
the congestion problems on the corridor will require a multifaceted approach consisting of
managing existing signals to improve throughput, increasing long-term capacity, maintaining the
access points which the existing retail requires, and planning for future developments in a way
that balances access with mobility. The short, mid, and long-term recommendations are
summarized below.

SHORT-TERM RECOMMENDATIONS
Modify Access Points Close to SR 54 at SR 74 Intersection
   • Install a continuous green “T” signal at the existing intersection of SR 54 and Market
       Place Boulevard/The Avenue. Cut off Market Place Boulevard from SR 54 and redirect
       traffic to a proposed new signal at the intersection of SR 74 and Westpark Drive.
   •   Restrict left turns to and from Commerce Drive at its intersection with SR 54, by
       converting this intersection to a right-in and right-out only. These left turns would be
       redirected to the new signal as well.
Modify Bottleneck Intersection of Planterra Way to Improve Efficiency of Side Street Movements
  • Widen the northbound approach of Planterra Way to accommodate an exclusive left turn
       lane. The median nose that sticks out into the intersection from the east can be
       shortened to allow a broader turn radius for left turns exiting the Wal-Mart/The Home
       Depot driveway. The intersection should be widened to the point that both side-street
       left turn movements can operate concurrently, and thereby removing the need to split-
       phase the signal.




                                           - 43 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                         State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                        Peachtree City, GA


Modify MacDuff Parkway Intersection to Accommodate Current Needs and Additional Traffic
due to Planned Development
   • Widen the southbound approach of MacDuff Parkway and construct a northbound left
       turn lane into the Discount Tire retail site. This northbound left turn lane should be
       adjacent and parallel to the existing southbound left turn lane to prevent an end-to-end
       geometric condition that limits the length of both directional turn lanes. Additionally, the
       widening should accommodate a second southbound left turn lane to aid in meeting
       peak demand for this turning movement.
   •   Construct an access road to connect the Overlook development to MacDuff Parkway via
       the MacDuff Crossing shopping center. Coordination will be required between the
       developer, the city, and the owner of the MacDuff Crossing property. Additionally, an
       exclusive left turn lane should be constructed at the existing signal on the northbound
       driveway of MacDuff Crossing.
Signalize the Intersection of SR 54 and Line Creek Drive with a Continuous Green “T” to
Accommodate Additional Traffic due to Planned Development
   • Upon completion of The Overlook development at Line Creek Drive, the access point
        should be given a traffic signal in the form of a continuous green “T”. The northern leg of
        the existing intersection should be converted into a right-in/right-out driveway. The side
        street left turns should be guided by a channelization island into an added lane that will
        end approximately 660’ from the proposed signal where the lane will become the
        westbound left turn lane into MacDuff Crossing. The 660’ section should be designed to
        allow cars from The Overlook to weave with cars turning left into MacDuff Crossing.

MID-TERM RECOMMENDATIONS
Modify Bottleneck Intersection of Huddleston Rd. to Improve Efficiency of Side Street
Movements
   • Realign the northbound approach of Huddleston Road and widen it to accommodate a
      dual left turn lane. The realignment should be designed to position Huddleston at a
      perpendicular intersection with SR 54, rather than the skew that it currently has. This
      realignment makes drivers more visible to oncoming traffic from the Best Buy driveway.
      In addition to the realignment, the grade should be adjusted to reduce the hill climbing
      needed prior to entering the intersection.
Provide Additional Capacity along SR 54 in the Congested Westbound Direction
   • The southbound right turn lane on SR 74 north of its intersection with SR 54 should be
       lengthened back to the existing right-in/right-out driveway of Market Place Boulevard. A
       free-flowing lane should be constructed in the westbound direction on SR 54 beginning
       at this extended right turn lane. This lane will require reconstruction of existing curb and
       gutter just west of the intersection of SR 54 and SR 74, but should transition into the
       existing footprint before reaching the CSX railroad bridge crossing. At this transition
       point, the existing median will be used to construct a third through lane that will continue
       along the corridor through the intersection with MacDuff Parkway and then taper back
       down to the existing two lanes.


                                           - 44 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                        State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                       Peachtree City, GA


   •   As a mid-to-long range project, the city should consider coordinating with GDOT and the
       counties of Fayette and Coweta to extend the 6-lane section of SR 54 from MacDuff
       Parkway to Fischer Road in Coweta County. This intersection represents the
       convergence point of several major state routes (SR 54 and SR 34) as well as the
       arterial road, Lower Fayetteville Road. Future growth will continue to escalate peak hour
       traffic volumes and therefore, the ultimate goal of an inter-county connection with
       appropriate capacity should be a priority for the city and other invested parties.
Connect Commerce Drive area to Residential Area to the Northeast
   • Construct a new roadway between Westpark Drive and Aberdeen Parkway to promote
      use of the new signal and to provide a direct connection to retail on SR 54 for residences
      to the north on Flat Creek Road and Riley Parkway.
Provide Additional Capacity along SR 54 in the Eastbound Direction and East of SR 74
   • Create a third eastbound through lane on SR 54 by converting the existing median into a
       travel lane. This lane should extend from west of MacDuff Parkway through the
       intersection with SR 74. The resulting highway will be a 6-lane road constructed in two
       phases.
   •   Extend the third through lane in the westbound direction back through the intersection of
       SR 54 and SR 74 to Commerce Drive. This will involve widening the intersection to
       accommodate an extra lane in each direction.
Plan Parallel Connections to SR 54 Corridor
   • Coordinate with County and regional planning efforts, such as the Fayette County
       Comprehensive Transportation Plan (CTP) and Atlanta Regional Transportation Plan
       (RTP) to examine and develop new parallel connections between Fayette County and
       Coweta County. These include connections north – between SR 54 and Castlewood
       Road and south – between SR 54 and Rockaway Road.

LONG-TERM RECOMMENDATIONS
Improve Capacity at Critical Intersection
   • A Continuous Flow Intersection (CFI) or a left turn overpass at the crossing of state
      routes 54 and 74 is recommended. Either alternative is expected to provide adequate
      levels of service on all approaches and would not limit existing access points to retail in
      the quadrants of the intersection. The footprint of either option is not expected to require
      removal of any structures, but could require use of retaining walls on the northern side of
      the southwest-bound leg where steep grades down to Westpark Walk’s parking lot
      currently exist.
Construct Parallel Connections to SR 54 Corridor
   • Construct new parallel connections between Fayette County and Coweta County.
       These include connections north – between SR 54 and Castlewood Road and south –
       between SR 54 and Rockaway Road.




                                           - 45 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                        State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                       Peachtree City, GA


PROJECT COSTS
The recommended projects indicated above were examined to determine planning level cost
estimates. These costs are based on cost data from GDOT, ARC, and Pond & Company
experience. They were prepared using the preliminary concepts developed for this study. The
project descriptions and costs are provided in Table 19. This Table indicates the following
breakdown of costs by implementation timeframe:
    • Short Term (2014 – 2020): $2.7 million
    • Mid-Term (2020 - 2030): $9.3 million
    • Long-Term (2030 – 2040): $5 million to $15 million

Please note, planning and construction of new parallel connections between Fayette County
and Coweta County are recommended, but are not included in the project list provided in Table
19. Graphics illustrating the location and types of improvements recommended in this study are
shown in Figures 12-14.


PROJECT PRIORITIZATION
Although the project list shows implementation timeframes, it is important to note that no funding
has been committed for any of the projects indicated in this report and implementation
timeframes are based on desired implementation to meet travel needs.

Determining which projects should be accomplished first and which are lower priority requires
consideration of a variety of factors. Many of these factors has subjective components that
could lead to differences of opinion regarding which projects to implement first. In addition, the
availability of funding is a consideration for project implementation. Table 19 contains an
evaluation of each project versus its ability to satisfy transportation goals and objectives.

PROJECT FUNDING
Funding of transportation improvements is at a critical stage. With potential depletion of the
Highway Trust Fund and the expiration of the current Moving Ahead for Progress in the 21st
Century Act (MAP-21) federal legislation in September 2014, federal resources are strained and
future funding priorities and levels are uncertain. MAP-21 was signed into law in July 2012,
funding surface transportation programs at $105 billion for fiscal years (FY) 2013 and 2014.
MAP-21 is the first long-term highway authorization enacted since 2005. MAP-21 creates a
performance-based, multimodal program to address the challenges of improving safety,
maintaining infrastructure condition, reducing traffic congestion, improving efficiency of the
system and freight movement, protecting the environment, and reducing delays in project
delivery.

MAP-21 builds on and refines many of the highway, transit, bike, and pedestrian programs and
policies established with the previous transportation bill, the Intermodal Surface Transportation
Efficiency Act (ISTEA) in 1991. This summary below indicates the funding programs
administered by the Federal Highway Administration under Map-21.
•   The Surface Transportation Program (STP) provides flexible funding that may be used by
    states and localities for projects to preserve and improve the conditions and performance on
    any federal-aid highway, bridge and tunnel projects on any public road, pedestrian and
    bicycle infrastructure, and transit capital projects, including intercity bus terminals. A portion
    of the STP urban funds administered by the Atlanta Regional Commission (ARC) are used
    to support the following programs, in accordance with the ARC Regional Transportation
    Plan (RTP):
    o   Roadway Operations and Safety
    o   Last Mile Connectivity
    o   Livable Centers Initiative
    o   Transit Capital and Preventative Maintenance


•   The National Highway Performance Program (NHPP) provides support for the condition
    and performance of the National Highway System (NHS), for the construction of new
    facilities on the NHS, and to ensure that investments of federal-aid funds in highway
    construction are directed to support progress toward the achievement of performance
    targets established in a state's asset management plan for the NHS.
•   Transportation Alternatives Program (TAP) – MAP-21 established a new program to
    provide for a variety of alternative transportation projects, including many that were
    previously eligible activities under separately funded programs. The TAP replaces the
    funding from pre-MAP-21 programs including Transportation Enhancement, Recreational
    Trails, Safe Routes to School, and several other discretionary programs, wrapping them into
    a single funding source.


                                            - 52 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                         State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                        Peachtree City, GA


•   Congestion Mitigation and Air Quality (CMAQ) - The CMAQ program provides a flexible
    funding source to state and local governments for transportation projects and programs to
    help meet the requirements of the Clean Air Act. Funding is available to reduce congestion
    and improve air quality for areas that do not meet the National Ambient Air Quality
    Standards for ozone, carbon monoxide, or particulate matter (nonattainment areas) and for
    former nonattainment areas that are now in compliance (maintenance areas).

In addition to federal funding, it is possible to receive funding from the State of Georgia for
improvement of safety and traffic operations along state routes. State Transportation Funding
also includes the following programs which may be applicable to Peachtree City:

•   Local Maintenance & Improvement Grant (LMIG) Program – LMIG funds are state
    funding provided to Cities and Counties for local maintenance and improvements. This
    funding is based on a combination of state road miles and population and can be used for a
    variety of purposes, including:
       a. Preliminary engineering (including engineering work for R/W plans and Utility plans)
       b. Construction supervision & inspection
       c. Utility Adjustments or replacement
       d. Patching, leveling and resurfacing a paved roadway
       e. Grading, Drainage, Base and Paving existing or new roads
       f. Replacing storm drain pipe or culverts
       g. Intersection improvements
       h. Turn lanes
       i. Bridge repair or replacement
       j. Sidewalk adjacent (within right of way) to a public roadway or street
       k. Roadway Signs, striping, guardrail installation
       l. Signal installation or improvement
       m. Aggregate Surface Course for dirt road maintenance

•   Georgia’s Operational Improvement Program – This program provides Lump Sum
    Funding allotted for “Quick Fix” projects to improve operations for a low cost (ideally <$1
    million). The scope consists mainly of geometric improvements to existing intersections,
    freeway ramps or minor ITS projects on state routes. Ten to Twenty projects selected are
    selected each year based on operational benefit. The candidate location does not have to
    have a high Safety priority. Consideration of Innovative Intersection alternatives is strongly
    encouraged. The preconstruction schedule should fit within 6‐18 months.




                                           - 53 -
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                                         State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                                        Peachtree City, GA


•   Georgia Transportation Infrastructure Bank - The Georgia Transportation Infrastructure
    Bank (GTIB) provides loans to state, regional, and local government entities to fund eligible
    transportation projects. GTIB is also authorized to administer grant money for specific
    programs related to transportation.        The objectives in administering the Georgia
    Transportation Infrastructure Bank shall be to:
       1. Make an additional funding resource available to government units in order to initiate
       and complete transportation projects.
       2. Give priority to bridge and highway (road) projects that are close to the start of, at, or
       under construction, have a higher degree of contributed matching funds, and have been
       initiated by government units, particularly cities and counties. (Transit and airport
       projects are currently ineligible for GTIB assistance due to the fact that the primary GTIB
       funding is from Motor Fuel Taxes).
       3. Select projects for financing that add transportation and economic value to local
       communities and/or the State.
       4. Ensure consistency, fairness, and efficiency in the evaluation of applications.
       5. Provide for a smooth operational process that maintains loan and grant documents,
       manages the GTIB's capital prudently, tracks loan expenditures/repayments, and
       provides adequate reporting.

In addition to funding of improvements through state and federal sources, funding of
improvements through local sources, such as the special purpose local option sales tax
(SPLOST), and Community Improvement Districts (CIDs) has allowed local government
agencies to provide significant funding for transportation improvements through locally funded
projects or by applying local funding to match available federal funds.

Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                       State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                      Peachtree City, GA

                                           APPENDIX A:
                  DOCUMENTATION OF TRAVEL DEMAND MODEL WORK
                                                  
 




 


April 14, 2014


SUBJECT:         Traffic Study of SR 54 from McDuff Parkway to
                 Willow Bend Road/Flat Creek Road

                 Technical Memorandum
                 Documentation of Travel-Demand Modeling Work


This technical memorandum includes the methodology and results in connection with the travel-
demand modeling services provided for the traffic study referenced above. The attachments of
this document include tables with detailed information as well as model-output plots that show
the traffic volumes that correspond to the different scenarios that were modeled according to our
scope of services.



Introduction:
Several travel-demand model scenarios were conducted to assess existing and future
conditions of SR 54, in the vicinity of SR 74, in Peachtree City, Fayette County, Georgia. The
Atlanta Regional Commission (ARC )Travel-Demand Model - Plan 2040 Version, dated January
2013, was used for all model scenarios related to this project, including:


       2013 West Village Existing Conditions
       2040 base future conditions
       Future Alternative 1, and
       Future Alternative 2.


Minimal necessary edits were made to the ARC model to better reflect 2013 conditions for the
West Village development land uses and access, as well as for the proposed build-out
conditions of the West Village development. Future conditions included the addition of McDuff
Parkway added to the model network, as well as one alternative with TDK Boulevard extended
to McIntosh Trail, in Coweta County.



                                                                                         Page | 1 
 
                                                   
 




Methodology:
To better adapt the regional model to local conditions within the study area, several edits were
necessary. Traffic Analysis Zone (TAZ) centroid 1403, which was representative of both the
West Village area land uses in the northwest quadrant of SR 54 at SR 74, and the more
industrial land uses west of Senoia Road at Crabapple Lane, was split into two TAZs. TAZ
1403 remained west of Senoia Road, with the southward connection to SR 54 deleted, and the
eastward connection to Senoia Road at Kendron Drive relocated to Crabapple Lane.
Residential, Retail and Service land uses were re-assigned from TAZ 1403, to new TAZ 1570
placed just north of SR 54 and connected to SR 54 at McDuff Parkway. Household, population
and household by income group values were factored up to represent existing conditions of the
West Village development. Details of the socio-economic data revisions are shown in Table A-1,
provided under the attachments of this document.


For future condition Alternatives 1 and 2, McDuff Parkway was added to the model network from
SR 54 to Senoia Road at Kendron Drive.          Kendron Drive was also added to the network
between Senoia Road and SR 74. The TAZ connectors representing Kendron Drive were edited
to reflect the addition of this roadway. For both future alternatives, TAZ 1403 was again split into
TAZ 1403 and TAZ 1570, following the same methodology explained above. TAZ 1570 was
connected to SR 54 at Huddleston Rd and to the southern extent of McDuff Parkway, just north
of SR 54.    Household and population data associated with TAZ 1570 was limited to 2013
conditions. A new TAZ, number 1572, was added to the future alternatives to represent the
approved and proposed land uses for the build out of the West Village development. This new
TAZ was connected to McDuff Parkway at two locations near the mid-point and north end of the
proposed alignment, to better reflect proposed future conditions when loading the model
network with site generated traffic. Alternative 1 included the extension of TDK Boulevard west
of Dividend Drive, to McIntosh Trail in Coweta County.


Model files edited for existing and future alternative modeling scenarios were limited to the
following:    NWTAZ{year}G.PRN,          HSHLD{year}G.DAT,         ARC{year}HWY1.NET,           and
taz2027_realcentroid.dbf, and are included with the electronic files submitted along with this
technical memorandum. All model runs were conducted as Time of Day (TOD) models. An



                                                                                            Page | 2 
 
                                                
 




additional model run was conducted as a base for future conditions comparison. The 2040
Base TOD model was ran as “out-of-the-box” with no edits to model files.


2012 Georgia Department of Transportation (GDOT) AADT traffic counts in the vicinity of the
study area were compared to model output volumes for existing conditions as part of a
reasonableness check. While there were some differences noted between GDOT counts and
model volumes in the vicinity of the study area, the differences along SR 54 at McDuff Parkway,
where model edits were made to reflect existing conditions, were minimal and within reason. It
should be taken into consideration that he ARC model is a regional model when assessing
reasonableness of local conditions.


Results:
The results of the four model scenarios are shown in the Attachments in Table A-2, and the
plots on the pages following the table. Table A-2 compares model output volumes and GDOT
AADT counts (where available), by road segment in the vicinity of the study area. Pages A-3 to
A-6 display the model network and link volumes for each modeling scenario.




                                                                                        Page | 3 
Traffic Study of SR 54 from MacDuff                      State Route 54 Corridor
Pkwy. to Willowbend Road/Flat Creek Road                     Peachtree City, GA

                                       Analyzed           Maximum        Note
Weaving flow rate, Vw                  213                2800            a
Average flow rate (pcphpl)             911                                b
Volume ratio, VR                       0.08               0.45            c
Weaving ratio, R                       0.09                N/A            d
Weaving length (ft)                    790                2500            e
Notes:
a. Weaving segments longer than 2500 ft. are treated as isolated merge and
    diverge areas using the procedures of Chapter 25, "Ramps and Ramp
    Junctions".
b. Capacity constrained by basic freeway capacity.
c. Capacity occurs under constrained operating conditions.
d. Three-lane Type A segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater
    than 0.45. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such
    cases.
e. Four-lane Type A segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater
    than 0.35. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such
    cases.
f. Capacity constrained by maximum allowable weaving flow rate: 2,800 pc/h
    (Type A), 4,000 (Type B), 3,500 (Type C).
g. Five-lane Type A segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater
    than 0.20. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such
    cases.
h. Type B weaving segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater
    than 0.80. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such
    cases.
i. Type C weaving segments do not operate well at volume ratios greater
    than 0.50. Poor operations and some local queuing are expected in such
    cases.
